instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message: Came in heavily corroded.  I ultrasonic cleaned and reaplced both bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> and now computer is turning on.  everything is working execpt there is no sound.  sound is being detected in system prefs but sound is coming out of speakers.  i found a couple of shorts around <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> so i removed it and shorts went away.  replaced it and all is good, but still not getting sound.  the only issue is a short to ground on <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_RL_MODE</SIGNAL>.  i replaced <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> again and replaced <RESISTOR>R6481</RESISTOR> but still same issue.  if i remove the resistor the short to ground goes away. i  am at a loss on this.  did i get 2 bad chips?  is this suppose to show short to ground?. i don't think so becuase <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_FL_MODE</SIGNAL> is not on <CHIP>U6450</CHIP> side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6481</RESISTOR> is 0 ohm resistor, CONNECTED to ground; what value did you expect to get there?

Corrosion under (or around) <CHIP>U6400</CHIP>/50 is very dangerous; several T2 lines are connected there.
Leakage from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> damaged T2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message: Just trying to understand here.  if t2 was damaged wouldn't that stop the laptop from powering on?  and second question.  Since <CAPACITOR>C6406</CAPACITOR> was short to ground (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SPKRAMP_LEFT</SIGNAL>) wouldn't that have stopped power from going to t2?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message:
T2 is a complex chip; it may get partial damage only.
One time I got 01521 with <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_RESET_L</SIGNAL> shorted to ground because of liquid spill on audio board.
Machine had even heaphones sound, but nothing on internal speakers.

There was sufficient time for leakage to T2 lines, before <CAPACITOR>C6406</CAPACITOR> shorted <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 88177, member: 682"]
Machine had even heaphones sound, but nothing on internal speakers.
[/QUOTE]

is the same issue on this board.  is there any way to test to make sure t2 is bad?  should i take <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> off and test the lines?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message:
I don't see other reason, as you found corrosion there.

Some lines may have test points, or external components connected.
Other lines can only be accessed under audio amps.
However, is wasting time to remove the chips; the problem is clear...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message: just for an update on this case.  i ordered a donor board and dioded tested all the pads comparing to the working board.  found a reading that was off and found a resistor that was not to spec.  replaced it along both chips and now have speakers.  moral of the story is test all the lines :)
